emulators.name: FUSE
emulators.desc: Free Unix Spectrum Emulator. 48k adn 128k spectrum, also others like pentagon and brazilian clone tk90x

emulators.name: ZEsarUX
emulators.desc: Free Unix Spectrum Emulator. 48k adn 128k spectrum, also others like pentagon and brazilian clone tk90x

emulators.name: Vice
emulators.desc: A 8 bit emulator for 8 bit Commodore Machines, includes C64, C128, VIC20, PET, etc

emulators.name: linapple
emulators.instructions: [F1] - Help </br> CTRL + [F2] - Could Boot </br> CTRL + [F10] - Hot Reset (Control + Reset) </br> [F12] - Exit

emulators.name: minivmac
emulators.instructions: CTRL + H - Help </br> CTRL + Q - Exit

emulators.name: basiliskII
emulators.instructions: CTRL + H - Help </br> CTRL + Q - Exit

systems.name: ZX Spectrum 48kb
systems.desc: The ZX Spectrum was among the decade’s best-selling computers, captivating millions via its iconic rubber keys and vibrant gaming library. 16kb or 48kb, color

systems.name: Spectrum 128
systems.desc: The ZX Spectrum 128, released in 1985–86, expanded RAM to 128 KB and Spectrum+ keyboard.

systems.name: Microdigital TK90X
systems.desc: The Microdigital TK90X, introduced in 1985, is a Brazilian clone of the Sinclair ZX Spectrum. It uses a Z80A CPU, offers 16–48KB RAM, BASIC ROM, CMOS graphics, and TV output.

systems.name: Microdigital TK95
systems.desc: The Microdigital TK95, released in 1986, is an evolution of the TK90X with an enhanced mechanical keyboard, Z80A CPU, 48 KB RAM, 16 KB ROM, composite video output, and built-in joystick ports, housed in a plastic case.

systems.name: PET
systems.desc: 1977’s Commodore PET launched with a MOS 6502 CPU at 1 MHz, 4 KB RAM, and a built-in cassette drive.

systems.name: Commodore 64
systems.desc: 1982’s Commodore 64 featured a MOS 6510 CPU at 1 MHz, 64 KB RAM, and the iconic SID sound chip.

systems.name: Commodore 128
systems.desc: 1985’s Commodore 128 offered dual CPUs (8502 at 2 MHz, Z80 at 4 MHz), 128 KB RAM, and three modes.

systems.name: Amiga 500+
systems.desc: 16 Bit computer

systems.name: Hotbit 1.2
systems.desc: Brazilian MSX 1.2

systems.name: Expert 1.1
systems.desc: Brazilian MSX 1

systems.name: VG8000
systems.desc: Philips MSX 1.0

systems.name: FS-5500 F2
systems.desc: Nationa FS-5500 F2 MSX2

systems.name: FS-A1WSX
systems.desc: Panasonic MSX2+

systems.name: Boosted MSX2
systems.desc: GFX9000, Moonsound, FMPac, SCC+

systems.name: FS-A1GT
systems.desc: Panasonic MSX Turbo R

systems.name: Amiga 1000
systems.desc: 1985’s Commodore Amiga 1000 shipped with a Motorola 68000 CPU at 7.16 MHz, 256 KB RAM, and the custom OCS chipset.

systems.name: ZX81
systems.desc: The Sinclair ZX81 revolutionized home computing in 1981, offering affordable programming, minimal graphics, and inspiring a hobbyist community, sparking innovation

systems.name: Cambridge Z88
systems.desc: The Cambridge Z88, launched in 1987, pioneered portable computing with battery efficiency, integrated software suite, and compact design for professionals.

systems.name: Sinclair QL
systems.desc: The Sinclair QL, launched in 1984, was an affordable business microcomputer with a Motorola 68008 CPU and innovative microdrive storage

systems.name: Sam Coupe
systems.desc: The Sam Coupé was an 8-bit microcomputer manufactured by Miles Gordon Technology in 1989, featuring advanced graphics, stereo sound, microdrives.

systems.name: ZX Uno
systems.desc: The ZX-Uno is an FPGA-based ZX Spectrum clone, crowdfunded in 2016, featuring SD card storage, PS/2 keyboard, composite video, audio.

systems.name: ZX Spectrum NEXT
systems.desc: The ZX Spectrum Next is an FPGA-based developed by Victor Truco and launched in 2017 offering Z80 at 28 MHz, 2 MB RAM, HDMI, SD storage.

systems.name: CPC 464
systems.desc: The Amstrad CPC 464 launched in 1984 with integrated cassette drive, 64 KB RAM, vibrant graphics, BASIC, and affordable home computing

systems.name: CPC 664
systems.desc: Launched in 1985 offered 64 KB RAM, built-in 3-inch floppy drive, sleek design, vivid graphics, and BASIC.

systems.name: CPC 6128
systems.desc: The Amstrad CPC 6128 released in 1985 featured 128 KB RAM, built-in 3-inch floppy disk, advanced BASIC, and vibrant display modes.

systems.name: Amiga 500
systems.desc: 1987’s Commodore Amiga 500 featured a 7.16 MHz Motorola 68000, 512 KB RAM, and the Agnus, Denise, Paula custom chips.

systems.name: Amiga 1200
systems.desc: 1992’s Commodore Amiga 1200 shipped with a 14 MHz Motorola 68EC020 CPU, 2 MB RAM, AGA chipset, and a PCMCIA slot.

systems.name: Amiga 4000 (HD)
systems.desc: 1992’s Commodore Amiga 4000 delivered a 25 MHz Motorola 68040 CPU, 2 MB Fast RAM expandable, and the AGA chipset.

systems.name: Apple ][ Plus
systems.desc: Released June 1979, the Apple II Plus added Integer BASIC and 16–48 KB RAM support, offering color graphics and expansion slots, and became a major success.

systems.name: Apple //e
systems.desc: Released January 1983, the Apple IIe featured a 1 MHz 6502 CPU, 64 KB RAM (expandable to 128 KB), ProDOS support, durable keyboard.

systems.name: Performa System 7.5.5
systems.desc: The Macintosh Performa running System 7.5.5 delivers classic Mac OS features, multimedia performance, and intuitive, user-friendly computing in vintage style

systems.name: Macintosh 128 system 1.1
systems.desc: Macintosh 128K, released in 1984, achieved success with a Motorola 68000 CPU at 8 MHz, 128 KB RAM, 9-inch monochrome display, and GUI mouse interface.

systems.name: Macintosh 128 system 2.2
systems.desc: Macintosh 128K, released in 1984, achieved success with a Motorola 68000 CPU at 8 MHz, 128 KB RAM, 9-inch monochrome display, and GUI mouse interface.

systems.name: TRS-80 Model III
systems.desc: Released in 1980, used a Zilog Z80A at 2.03 MHz with 16–48 KB RAM and cassette storage.

systems.name: TRS Color Computer 2
systems.desc: The TRS-80 Color Computer 2, introduced in 1983, featured a Motorola 6809E at 0.895 MHz, 16–64 KB RAM, and 256×192 graphics.

systems.name: Microdigital CP-500
systems.desc: Introduced in 1982 by Prológica as a Brazilian clone of the TRS-80 Model III, the CP-500 ran a Zilog Z80A at 2 MHz with 16–48 KiB RAM and used floppy-disk storage.

systems.name: Atari 800
systems.desc: Debuting in 1979, the 800 offered a 1.79 MHz MOS 6502, expandable 8–48 KB RAM, and 320×192 high-resolution graphics

systems.name: Atari 800XL
systems.desc: Released in 1983 by Atari, the 800XL featured a 1.79 MHz MOS 6502C CPU, 64 KB RAM, and 320×192 graphics.

systems.name: Atari ST
systems.desc: Released in 1985, Atari’s 520ST ran a Motorola 68000 CPU at 8 MHz with 512 KiB RAM, 320×200 color graphics; floppy-disk storage.

systems.name: Falcon 030
systems.desc: Introduced in 1992, Atari’s Falcon 030 ran a Motorola 68030 at 16 MHz with 1 MB RAM (expandable), onboard DSP, MIDI ports, and SVGA graphics.

systems.name: VIC 20
systems.desc: Introduced in 1980, the VIC-20 featured a 1.1 MHz MOS 6502 CPU, 5 KB RAM, 176×184 graphics, and cartridge-based storage
